qas.question: What additional influences were incorporated into neoclassical architecture by mid 18th century?
In what city did a generation of French art students study that propelled neoclassical architecture and incorporation broader styles?
What other countries adopted the style of neoclassical?

plausible_answers.text: a greater range of Classical influences

qas.question: What did movement incorporate by the mid-1800s?
When was the shift to classical architecture dated?
What archaeological dig influence the classical period?
What was influenced by Roman art students trained in France?
Where was neoclassical architecture adopted in conventional circles?

context: By the mid 18th century, the movement broadened to incorporate <b4_0>a greater range of Classical influences<b4_0/>, including those from <a0_0>Ancient Greece<a0_0/>. The shift to <b7_0>neoclassical architecture<b7_0/> is conventionally dated to the <b5_0>1750s<b5_0/>. It first gained influence in England and France; in England, <a1_0>Sir William Hamilton<a1_0/>'s excavations at <b6_0>Pompeii<b6_0/> and other sites, the influence of the Grand Tour and the work of William Chambers and Robert Adam, was pivotal in this regard. In France, the movement was propelled by a generation of French art students trained in <a2_0>Rome<a2_0/>, and was influenced by the writings of Johann Joachim Winckelmann. The style was also adopted by progressive circles in other countries such as <a3_0><b8_0>Sweden and Russia<b8_0/>.
